Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Interacting effects of disturbances on population demography
Award.AbstractNarration:
Hurricane disturbances may have large negative impacts on wildlife restricted to small coastal islands, through intense rain, wind, and storm surge. Paradoxically, hurricane disturbance may also regenerate certain habitats that particular species of wildlife depend on. The goal of this research is to investigate the interaction of a periodic, small scale disturbances such as fire, with an extreme disturbance (hurricane) on population growth and survival of an endangered butterfly species, Bartram's scrub-hairstreak (Strymon acis bartrami) and its rare host, pineland croton (Croton linearis). These species are patchily distributed throughout South Florida in rockland habitat, which was recently struck by the eyewall of Hurricane Irma. Results from this research will inform management of fourteen sensitive plants and animals in South Florida, including three additional endangered butterfly species affected by Hurricane Irma. By understanding the mechanisms of how one endangered insect-plant host pair responds to interacting disturbances, this project will provide insight into how these disturbances might influence other sensitive species. This project will also provide research training for a postdoctoral fellow and for undergraduate students.

This project will test the hypothesis that hurricanes interact synergistically with more regular, localized disturbances to accelerate habitat change. Based on existing data from an ongoing experiment and observational data on the distribution of the study organisms in relation to previous hurricane disturbances, researchers will test the hypothesis that the two types of disturbances will interact synergistically to increase host plant recruitment and mortality. Prior research has already measured vital rate responses to management-based disturbance (understory removal to simulate wildfire), and this RAPID project will measure vital rate responses to hurricane disturbance and the interaction between management and hurricane disturbances. Empirical data will be used to parameterize demographic matrix models to predict population responses to future interacting disturbances, and to project populations across a range of disturbance frequencies, including frequencies of human-managed disturbances that can be controlled and frequencies of intense hurricanes that cannot be controlled.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF Project Outcomes Report

              As urbanization, species invasions, and global climate change accelerate, conservation of rare ecosystems increasingly relies on human intervention. This is especially true for species that are threatened due to loss of historic disturbance regimes in their natural habitats. Human development has curtailed the ability of disturbances to occur on the scales they once did historically, dunes no longer shift with ocean currents, forests no longer burn in regular intervals, and rivers no longer seasonally flood. In these cases, humans must maintain, or simulate historic disturbances to prevent local species extinctions. However, management-based disturbances do not happen in isolation. In pine savannahs of the southeastern United States, prescribed fire regimes periodically interact with hurricane disturbances. As frequency of major hurricanes increases with climate warming, understanding how populations are affected by the interaction between climate- and management-driven disturbance is necessary to design conservation strategies that allow species to persist.

              Following the direct impact of Hurricane Irma, we examined how human-driven habitat management interacted with a catastrophic weather event to affect population dynamics of a rare plant, pineland croton (Croton linearis), that is the only host for two endangered butterfly species, Bartram?s scrub hairstreak (Strymon acis bartrami), and Florida leafwing (Anaea troglodyta). Our three study species are endemic to south Florida pine rockland forests, and depend on frequent, low-intensity fires. Pine rockland habitat is highly fragmented due to urban development and requires active disturbance management; where humans do not manage pine rocklands, species are lost. Prior to Hurricane Irma?s landfall, we measured how croton vital rates (e.g., survival and germination) and population growth rates responded to prescribed fire in Everglades National Park and simulated fire through mechanical understory removal on Big Pine Key. Following the direct strike of Hurricane Irma (Figure 1), we asked how previous management affected the plant?s response to hurricane impacts.

              We found that different vital rates of survival and germination respond differently to the different types of disturbance. For example, prescribed fire and mechanical clearing both resulted in a flush of germination, the hurricane disturbance did not. All three disturbances decreased survival relative to control or no-disturbance conditions, but the magnitude of the decrease depended both on proximity to the storm?s center and prior management (Figure 2). This study, combined with others that measure the direction and magnitude of vital rate responses to multiple disturbances in different species, will allow us to identify general trends of species response.
